channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: These Unsinkable Tubes Could Help Harvest Energy From the Ocean
item.description: Researchers developed aluminum structures that trap air bubbles, making them able to float perpetually in even the harshest environments.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Constant Sexual Aggression Drives Female Tortoises to Walk Off Cliffs
item.description: On a remote island in North Macedonia, male Hermann’s tortoises outnumber females 19 to 1, an imbalance driving the population to extinction.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Preston

item.title: Elephant Bone in Spain May Be Proof of Hannibal’s Tanks With Trunks
item.description: Archaeologists say a 2,200-year-old specimen is the first direct evidence of how the Carthaginian war machine used the giant mammals in the Punic Wars.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.media:credit: Adam Eastland/Alamy
item.media:description: A Renaissance-era fresco attributed to Jacopo Ripanda depicting Hannibal on the back of an elephant during the Second Punic War, in the third century B.C.

item.title: An Elephant Is Blind Without Its Whiskers
item.description: There are about 1,000 tiny hairs on an elephant’s rugged trunk, all designed to help the animal feel, a new study found.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: TV, It’s Not Just for Humans Anymore
item.description: Videos aimed at pets are drawing millions of views. But who’s actually watching?
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Julia Rothman

item.title: This Comet Stopped Spinning. Then It Started Rotating Backward.
item.description: The unusual event, never seen before, might be a way small comets are “blown to bits” in the solar system.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan O’Callaghan

item.title: Baboon Sibling Rivalry Suggests Monkeys Feel Jealousy Like People
item.description: Young primates in a southern African nature park were observed to constantly interfere when their mother was giving attention to a younger brother or sister.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)
item.media:credit: Axelle Delaunay

item.title: Lost Soviet Luna 9 Moon Lander May Have Been Found
item.description: Two research teams have identified possible landing sites for Luna 9, the first human-made object to safely reach the lunar surface. “One of them is wrong,” an expert said.
item.dc:creator: Becky Ferreira

item.title: Vaccine Makers Curtail Research and Cut Jobs
item.description: Federal policies under Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that are hostile to vaccines have “sent a chill through the entire industry,” one scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Moderna says it plans to pull back on late-stage studies of some of its experimental vaccines.

item.title: Should Drug Companies Be Advertising to Consumers?
item.description: Aging means “becoming a target” of the industry, one expert said. After decades of debate, politicians of all stripes are proposing bans.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Luisa Jung

item.title: Could an Electronic Coach Help Ski Jumpers Leap Farther?
item.description: Future Olympic prospects are testing a device that can give them corrective advice in real time as they hurtle into the air.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Alfred Blumstein, Who Transformed the Study of Crime, Dies at 95
item.description: An engineer by training, he used systems theory and quantitative analysis to examine criminal behavior, revealing the systemic patterns of crime.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Trump Erased the Endangerment Finding. Here Come the Lawsuits.
item.description: The battle is expected to reach the Supreme Court, which is far more conservative today than it was when the measure was established.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump announced on Thursday that his administration would scrap the endangerment finding.

item.title: A Climate Supercomputer Is Getting New Bosses. It’s Not Clear Who.
item.description: The National Science Foundation said management of the machine, used by researchers for forecasts, disaster warnings and pure science, would be transferred to a “third-party operator.”
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Caine Delacy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The supercomputer is currently run from the National Center for Atmospheric Research headquarters in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: RFK Jr. Allies Target States to Overturn Vaccine Mandates for Schools
item.description: Proponents of vaccines warn that the efforts will further dismantle the immunization infrastructure and lead to more outbreaks of disease.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: An empty classroom at the high school in Williston, N.D., during an outbreak of measles there last year.

item.title: El Niño May Be Back This Summer, Bringing Drought and Floods
item.description: The powerful weather pattern is expected to shift into gear again around June, NOAA said, though its strength this time remains a question.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: David McNew/Getty Images
item.media:description: A storm in California during the last El Niño phase, in 2023. The El Niño weather pattern has far-reaching influence.

item.title: What to Know About the E.P.A.’s Big Attack on Climate Regulation
item.description: The Trump administration has repealed the scientific determination that underpins the government’s legal authority to combat climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Jenny Kane/Associated Press
item.media:description: E.P.A. administrator Lee Zeldin has claimed that previous administrations used the endangerment finding to justify “trillions of dollars” in regulations on polluting industries and its reversal will help the economy.

item.title: Trump Repeals Key Greenhouse Gas Finding, Erasing EPA’s Power to Fight Climate Change
item.description: The Environmental Protection Agency rejected the bedrock scientific finding that greenhouse gases threaten human life and well being. It means the agency can no longer regulate them.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Rigorous scientific findings since 2009 have shown that greenhouse gases and global warming are harming public health.

item.title: ‘Kramer/Fauci’ Revisits a Sparring Match During the AIDS Crisis
item.description: At the heart of Daniel Fish’s verbatim staging of a C-SPAN segment is a complex relationship, between Larry Kramer and Anthony Fauci, that “goes from ‘I hate you’ to ‘I love you’ and back.”
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez
item.category: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Jay Ryan as Larry Kramer in “Kramer/Fauci,” a verbatim staging of the 1993 televised clash between Anthony Fauci, who was the nation’s leading AIDS researcher, and Kramer, the playwright and activist.

item.title: 4 Months Trapped in a Hospital for an Obsolete Way of Treating Their Disease
item.description: Health workers in developing countries know that isolating tuberculosis patients is an outdated and potentially harmful practice, but lack the resources to move away from it.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Arlette Bashizi
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asta Djouma, a tuberculosis patient in isolation at the Djarengol Kodek Health Center in Maroua, northern Cameroon, who hasn’t seen her three children since she was admitted in October. “We’re just here,” she said.

item.title: Senate Questions Health Care Firm for Profiting Off Program Meant for Poor
item.description: The program was meant to help hospitals provide for poor patients by offering drug savings. But critics say a Texas company has turned it into a big business, driving up costs for patients and insurers.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The offices of Apexus in Irving, Texas. The company, a subsidiary of Vizient, negotiates drug discounts.

item.title: Satellite Pictures Show Snow And Ice Across North America
item.description: For much of North America, the last month has been an icy, frozen trudge. But from the right vantage point, it had a certain beauty.
item.dc:creator: Judson Jones and Leanne Abraham
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: New Method Can Find Hidden Eggs to Aid in Fertility Treatment
item.description: A study reported that the conventional method of searching follicular fluid didn’t find all the eggs. The new technology found extra eggs more than half the time.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A viable egg found by the OvaReady device that was not found using the conventional method.

item.title: Bans on Many CBD Products Loom This Year
item.description: A federal law taking effect in November severely limits the amount of THC, the euphoric cannabis compound, allowed in over-the-counter items. Many groups are fighting back.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: Four States Sue Administration Over Loss of Public Health Funds
item.description: The states, all led by Democrats, claim the cuts were intended as retribution and will harm efforts to control H.I.V. and other sexually transmitted infections.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The agency administered block grants for H.I.V. prevention that were allocated to public health departments in California, Colorado, Illinois and Minnesota.

item.title: Mexico May Be on Brink of Losing Its Measles-Free Status
item.description: The country’s confirmed cases have topped 9,000 since last year, raising fears that a high-stakes evaluation in April could lead to its status being revoked.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Marco Ugarte/Associated Press
item.media:description: A health worker administering a dose of the measles vaccine in Mexico City last week. “We are confident that the outbreak will be controlled,” President Claudia Sheinbaum said on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Orders Dept. of Defense to Buy Electricity From Coal Sources
item.description: Mr. Trump is trying to revive coal, the dirtiest fossil fuel. At the White House, coal executives awarded him a trophy as the “Undisputed Champion of Beautiful Clean Coal.”
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order. On the desk beside him is a trophy labeled “Undisputed Champion of Beautiful Clean Coal.”

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Defend Rejection of Moderna’s Flu Vaccine
item.description: The F.D.A.’s refusal to examine the company’s mRNA shot drew widespread criticism from doctors and was divisive within the agency.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Marty Makary, the F.D.A. commissioner, suggested that the agency might eventually approve Moderna’s mRNA flu vaccine.

item.title: Portland Lawsuit Alleges Tear Gas Use by ICE Is a Health Threat
item.description: A novel lawsuit in Portland argues the chemicals are a health threat that have soaked into apartment walls, furniture and even children’s toys.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: An October incident outside an ICE facility in Portland, Ore. Residents across the street have sued over the use of tear gas.

item.title: F.D.A. Refuses to Review Moderna Flu Vaccine
item.description: The vaccine maker’s shots involve the successful Covid vaccines’ RNA technology. Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has broadly rejected it, canceling millions of dollars in research projects.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: Moderna is a pioneer in using mRNA technology, first with the Covid vaccine. Its flu shot was being developed for people 50 and older.

item.title: Climate Change Is Erased From Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence for Judges
item.description: After Republican criticism, a group that offers professional resources to judges withdrew a climate science chapter from its Reference Manual on Scientific Evidence.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Chevron v Natural Resources Defense Council (Supreme Court Decision)
National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine
item.media:credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: J.B. McCuskey, the West Virginia attorney general, in Washington last month. He led the effort against the climate chapter in the judges’ handbook.

item.title: Behind the E.P.A.’s Rush to Repeal the Endangerment Finding
item.description: The agency is racing to repeal a scientific finding that requires it to fight global warming. Experts say the goal is to get the matter before the justices while President Trump is still in office.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura/Reuters
item.media:description: Lee Zeldin, the E.P.A. administrator, at the agency’s headquarters in Washington last year.

item.title: ‘Galileo’ Musical, Starring Raúl Esparza, Will Open on Broadway
item.description: The musical, called “Galileo,” will star Raúl Esparza, and is scheduled to open in December at the Shubert Theater.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson

item.title: Dr. Oz Says Drinking Is a ‘Social Lubricant.’ Some Experts Worry About That.
item.description: “Most of the harm that comes from alcohol,” said one researcher, is “due mostly or mainly to drinking with their buddies.”
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Edu Bayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most research examining the effects of alcohol in a controlled laboratory setting has ignored the social context in which most drinking occurs.

item.title: Seals Are Recruited to Study the Ocean Under Antarctic Glaciers
item.description: The environment is changing rapidly around the melting Thwaites Glacier. Seals can collect data in waters that ships could never reach.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Bok Jin Kim, Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The tags themselves don’t seem to bother the animals, but Ms. Cheon and Mr. Chung agreed the tagging process tugs on some complicated heartstrings.
